content: I didn't need the pro version, but I bought it to support the dev. The free version is amazing!

content: very good RPN calculator. User interface seems a bit incongruent with android.
replyContent:
Hey Justin,

Thanks for the review and support.  Yeah, it's always a challenge to fit SO many buttons (and quick-access functions) while maintaining a UI balance between the familiarity of a real calculator and Android's design guidelines.

Fear not though, I'll be doing some work on that front in future releases.

Thanks,
Sam

content: Calculator is excellent. Kinldy add an option to change bottom right button as "=" on basic mode. Most of the calculators has equal sign on bottom right. It is hard for me to locate it when making quick calculations.

content: Long time rpn user, since hp 41. Great to use. Love the history feature, not many calcs have it.

content: Very good basic scientific calculator with RPN. Really needs an Undo button. Recommend moving the random number generator to a pull down menu for infrequently used functions and replace with an Undo button.

content: It's unfortunate that RPN is such a niche these days, that physcial calculators are so prohibitively expensive compared to standard scientific models as a result, because in my opinion RPN is vastly superior to the algebraic mode of entry. Luckily, this app is a pretty much perfect alternative, and I can't recommend it highly enough. 10/10.
replyContent: Thanks for the support and great review!!!

content: Easy to use .. very handy to have on the phone... Great functionality

content: Good app for calculation! But if you can provide algebric and matrix related features then it will be more useful for scientific calculation.
replyContent: Thanks for the support and feedback!

content: Clever approach to history - scrollable in the calculation window or as a dedicated page. I like that there's no "ANS" key - I prefer the "=" as I like to see my full calculation. All the functionality I'll ever need or use and then some. The themes are great, plenty of memories, nice big screen, and I could go on and on. Great calculator. Another selling point for me is the developer makes the effort to comment on nearly every rating. That tells me he's involved and cares. Kudos! He's pretty much giving this great calculator away selling it for only 99 cents. Finally - to the person that says 0^0 producing an error is an issue - I respectfully submit that there is controversy surrounding what 0^0 actually resolves to, so this really is just one of two possible solutions.
replyContent:
Sam, thanks for the support, awesome review and 5 stars!!!  You are right on the 0^0 and I usually I look to wolfram for the most appropriate response, which is undefined in this case.  One day, I'd like to add more specific errors (undefined vs infinity, etc.)
- Sam

content: Best Android scientific calculator I've found that feels good.
replyContent: Thanks for the support and 5 stars!!!

content: Great calculator program. I tried many calculator apps and picked this one. I am an engineer and programmer and use it almost every day. Stupid question: How do I enter 1.23e+15? Add this to the help.
replyContent:
Steve,

Thanks for the support and review!  You can use the EEX button to enter an E (times ten to the) exponent.

content: The best

content: Love the UX and UI, combined with great functionality. Best scientific calculator on the Play Store. Favourite theme is Monokai.

content: Please correct me if I am wrong. I liked this app very much but this app can show up to only 20 recent results in its history. At first, I didn't know this limitation so I lost lots of important calculation results. Would you please increase the number of results saved in history? I am not talking about the stack. I need the history of the expressions. With the limited history, the app is not practical for business usage. Looking forward to your reply. I will change the review if it is better.
replyContent: Thanks for the support and review. Your assessment is accurate. I'll definitely consider increasing it in a future release.

content: This is a great calculator. Better than most, if not all others. Clean, functional and well designed. Developer even responds to enquiries! What's not to like? CalcTastic will be going on all our devices.

content: This can't do parentheses in equations?  SO disappointed.  It should be able to handle this equation: 6/2(2+1)=. All of my scientific calculators as well as realcalc allows you to use a parentheses this way. Calctastic does not.  In fact, the parenthesis buttons are pretty useless.  If you type (3+2) and type another number it gives you the answer of 5 and moves on to your next equation.  Wow.  Just, wow.  A scientific calculator should be able to handle  simply 9(5) and get 45.  You may as well remove the parentheses from the program if they aren't going to work like every scientific calculator on the planet. Seriously.
replyContent:
Hey Mike,

Implicit multiplication was added in a recent release.  It works with parenthesis as in your example.

Thanks,
-Sam

content: One litte thing: in algebraic mode, enter this: 1 + i = x 3 = The result is 3+3i (correct!) but the expression display shows 1 + i x 3 = instead of (1 + i) x 3 = Please fix! UPDATE: thanks for reply! The spacing diference is  too hard to notice IMO, it is better to add (..) around the complex numbers when it is required by algebra.
replyContent: Thanks for the review and feedback!  There's actually a difference between those, check out the spacing around the "+".

content: in a user interface. Customizable look, fine tuning of haptic feedback, and an easily scrollable history. I bought the upgrade not because I necessarily needed the features, but because I'm happy to support quality development. Thanks for a great app!

I'm very used to my HP 35s where the square root/squared key is the inverse of calctastic, x^2 is the shifted function. content: Been a RealCalc Plus user for a couple of years. I recently found CalcTastic Plus. Clearly the winner. As far as I can tell it's got all the functions of Realcalc and more including polar <-> rectangular conversion, a random number generator (which can output integer random numbers as well), and some rudimentary statistics which cleverly uses the registers in the stack as data storage . It also keeps a history not just of numerical results but also of the operations (extremely valuable when in RPN). And it's got a lot more unit conversions than RealCalc. What I'd like to see though is the "Eng SI " mode of Hiper Calc where results are displayed in m, k, M, G, T etc. Useful for, among other fields, electronics design. Moreover, an option to switch functions such as square root as primary instead of x-squared would be helpful for some users.  And an "undo" function as in RealCalc would be much appreciated as well. Been scouring for a better RPN scientific calculator for Android and I can't find any thus far.
replyContent: Thanks for the review and feedback!

content: I tried a few calculator apps and this was the best for me.   One feature request. At the moment, when an operator is pressed, x: is pushed to y: but the value is also retained in the x: register. Although x: is over-ridden by whatever is entered next, it can be distracting. I would prefer that (via an optional setting), x: was zeroed as soon as it was pushed to y:
replyContent:
Good idea and thank you for the feedback.  I will look into adding this in the next update.  
**Edit**
Version 2.0.2 has just been released with this option now available, along with some minor bug fixes.

content: It feels great to have a great scientific calculator on my phone to that allows me to do much of what I need to do. Thanks for this!
